Dear Ms. Banks:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
Description calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time is
1

required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in writing,
of the basis for the extension and the expected length of the
extension. The total time for the completion of the investigation
may not exceed 90 calendar days without written approval from
the chief administrator or his or her designee.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency opened a special evaluation on a foster home and
have not completed any work on that special evaluation, though
the agency has completed the foster home's renewal or annual
inspection. There is concern the agency is intentionally delaying
the completion of the special evaluation to delay the transfer of the
home.
Investigation Interviews
Complainant
On 1/2/2025 I interviewed Complainant about these allegations by
telephone. Complainant reported the agency called in a children
services complaint related to the licensed foster home in mid-
October of 2024, and did not initiate the special evaluation until
November 2024. Additionally, since November nothing more has
been entered into CWLM (Child Welfare Licensing Module)
system. Complainant reported per their contact with the agency, in
December 2024, the agency had no findings related to the special
evaluation, but there is nothing in CWLM. Also, Agency Worker
(AW) reported she is the assigned worker for the special
evaluation, but nothing was completed in the CWLM system by
AW. Complainant reported the agency completed the foster
family’s renewal inspection, but the agency still has not started the
special evaluation. Complainant reported AW had reported she
was working on the narrative for the special evaluation and she
had an extension for the special evaluation.
Chief Administrator (CA & Agency Worker (AW)
I spoke with CA and AW briefly by telephone on 1/10/2025. I
interviewed AW separately by telephone on 1/17/2025.
CA reported they are a very small agency, and AW is the
supervisor/licensing worker who was charged to complete the
special evaluation on Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s foster
home. CA reported AW said she had completed the special
evaluation and had responded to the department’s contact to her
about the status of that special evaluation. CA was initially not
clear whether she had been included on emails from Department
Person to AW about concerns with the case and the status of the
special evaluation, but she was able to locate the emails that
2

showed she had been. She provided a copy of the emails as
indicated below.
Agency Worker (AW): On 1/17/2025, I interviewed AW by
telephone. She reported she did not write up the special
evaluation report until 1/14/2025. She said she had previously
entered information and documents in CWLM, but she was not
sure where the information went. She admitted she had reported
to Department Person that she was waiting on the children service
worker’s report, and other data in order to complete Listening
Ear’s special evaluation report. She reported the latter was before
she received clarification sometime in December 2024 that she
did not need the children service worker’s report to finish Listening
Ear’s special evaluation report.
AW reported on 11/4/2024 she sent the Branch County
Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) worker and
supervisor an email that she was working on the special
evaluation. She did not recall a response from those DHHS
persons to her email. She said Listening Ear was not certain as
to how they were to act given that the foster care case was being
taken from them. She said DHHS reached out to her again on
12/18/2024 asking for an update related to the special evaluation
and she provided them an update and apprised them of the 45-
day extension. She said she provided the DHHS worker, DHHS
supervisor, the foster parents, and the adoption worker a copy of
the special evaluation report on 1/17/2025. As for a copy of the
report to the Listening Ear worker, AW reported that person had
been placed on suspension and later terminated in December
2024 due to concerns reported by DHHS, that lead to the
department taking the cases back.
Document Review:
CWLM Provider Record Review
On 1/2/2025 I reviewed the CWLM record for Foster Parent A and
Foster Parent B. At that time a 10/16/2024 intake was seen
related to four allegations pertaining to the foster home. There
was no initiation date entered, no social work contacts entered, or
documents uploaded related to the intake and allegations
pertaining to the foster home. The records also showed a
reevaluation report for Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s
renewal inspection signed/dated by AW and Chief Administrator
for 12/6/2024. This reevaluation report indicated a special
investigation was initiated during the licensing period on
10/14/2024 and that the special evaluation was currently on going.
3

My subsequent review of the foster parents’ CWLM record on
1/17/2025 showed a special evaluation initiation letter dated
10/16/2024 and a 11/30/2024 45-day letter to the foster parents
indicating a need for an extension on the special evaluation due to
the agency waiting on receipt of a copy of the children service
worker’s report. Both of these letters were created in CWLM by
AW on 1/3/2025. The special evaluation report was listed as
created in CWLM by AW on 1/14/2025. Chief Administrator
approved the special evaluation report in CWLM on 1/15/2025.
The uploaded, special evaluation report was dated 1/15/2025.
CA emails that showed a string of emails going back to 11/1/2024
related to the department taking the children’s cases back, efforts
needed to complete a borrowed home agreement with the foster
home; as well as 12/3/2024 and 12/19/2024 emails from
Department Person specifically related to questions about the
foster parents’ special evaluation, and its status, along with AW’s
response to Department Person via email on 12/19/2024 denoting
she was currently working on the special evaluation narrative.
That the special evaluation was created on 10/16/2024 and an
extension was requested on 11/30/2024.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed although the agency did not create or enter information
into CWLM timely, it initiated the special evaluation timely and
requested an extension timely when the evaluation was not
completed within 45 days of the special evaluation’s 10/16/2025
initiation date.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
Description shall complete a written report that includes all the following
information:
(c) Dates and places of contact, names and person interviewed,
and the names of the interviewees. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in the report.
Violation Additional Findings of Noncompliance
Type
Allegation The agency’s special evaluation report does not show verification
that the worker interviewed the youth placed in the home related
to the allegations in the special evaluation. Additionally, the report
listed the foster youth’s full name.
4

Investigation Interviews:
Chief administrator & Agency Worker
During my telephone contact with CA and AW on 1/3/2025 and
1/17/2025 respectively, both acknowledged that AW completed
the special evaluation on Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s
foster home.
Additionally, AW acknowledged that during the special evaluation,
she conducted interviews of the foster parents with the children
services worker, but not Youth C who was/is placed in the foster
home. She reported the agency made the decision to not
interview Youth C due to concerns by the foster parents that the
agency was causing trauma to Youth C. It was reported when
Youth C saw the agency staff Youth C feared the agency was
there to remove him from the home. AW reported they decided
they would use the notes from the children service worker’s
interview of the youth.
Document review:
I reviewed the agency’s special evaluation report for Foster Parent
A and Foster Parent B dated 1/15/2025 which:
• Did not show an interview with foster child, Youth C (age
11) who resides in the foster home related to interviews for
all three of the allegations that alleged a possible lack of
care related to the foster youth.
• Showed the special evaluation report’s analysis section
referenced the children services worker’s interview of Youth
C for two of the three allegations that related to allegations
with respect to the youth.
• Contained Youth C’s full name.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the agency included Youth C’s last name in the report.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327
Section (6) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
Description shall complete a written report that includes all the following
information:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing that the foster parent has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Violation Additional Findings
Type
5

Allegation The agency did not inform the foster parents in writing of their right
to attach a written response to the special evaluation.
Investigation Interviews:
Chief administrator & Agency Worker
During my telephone contact with CA and AW on 1/3/2025 and
1/17/2025 respectively, both acknowledged that AW completed
the special evaluation on Foster Parent A’s and Foster Parent B’s
foster home.
Foster Parent.
On 3/3/2025 I spoke with Foster Parent A by telephone. She
acknowledged receipt of the special evaluation report from AW on
1/17/2025 by email. She reported she did not receive a letter or
email indication that she and Foster Parent B can attach a written
respond to the report. She forwarded me a copy of the email AW
send her showing the special evaluation was attached.
Document review:
I reviewed Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s CWLM provider
record which showed:
• The special evaluation dated 1/15/2025.
• A special evaluation checklist showing check offs that a
copy of the report was provided to the foster parents, with
advisement of their rights, but there was no proof this
information was provided to the foster parents.
• No letter, email or social work contact showing the foster
parents were advised they can attach a written response to
the special evaluation report if they chose to do so.
An email from AW to Foster Parent A dated 1/17/2025 that
indicated:
“As requested, attached is the Special Evaluation report
which was completed for your home. Your home was found
to be in compliance with all licensing rules. If you have any
questions, please reach out and I am happy to answer
them.”
No advisement of a right to include a written response to
the special evaluation report.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the agency did not inform the foster parents of their write
to include a written response.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

Rule Code & MCL 722.120
Section
Description Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and shall
report to the department, when requested, the facts the
department requires with reference to the children upon forms
furnished by the department. Except as otherwise provided in this
subsection and subsection (4), records regarding children and
facts compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information. Records that are
confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
Violation Additional Findings
Type
Allegation The agency included confidential (MIC) language in its special
evaluation report. It referred to the children services worker as the
MIC Worker and therein denoted CPS’s involvement in the special
evaluation.
Investigation Interviews:
Chief administrator & Agency Worker
During my telephone contact with CA and AW on 1/3/2025 and
1/17/2025 respectively, both acknowledged that AW completed
the special evaluation on Foster Parent A’s and Foster Parent B’s
foster home.
Document review:
I reviewed the special evaluation report for Parent A and Foster
Parent B dated 1/15/2025 which showed:
• Maltreatment In Care (MIC) language was used. The report
stated the MIC Worker interviewed the youth, as well as,
included statements such as a ponderance of evidence to
substantiate, all of which showed Children’s Protective
Services involvement in the investigation.
7

Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the agency is in violation of act as they disclosed
confidential information within the Special Evaluation report.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
